description.narrative:
The STREPFIN 2 project is aimed to establish a Donor Fund Basket that will be fully funded to drive a nationally registered tripartite stakeholders# forum of the government, CSO and the private sector as a platform for sustained inter-sectoral collaboration that will redefine public finance process in Nigeria.
The STREPFIN 2 project is relevant because in Nigeria, we have large number of citizens that are not informed on the issue of public finance, they do not know how government generates revenue and what such revenue are utilized for. Consequently it becomes increasingly difficult to hold government accountable for the common resources. Remedying such a situation requires building of active citizens able to engage with the agencies of government in Nigeria to promote transparency and accountability. Achieving this entails carrying out economic literacy from the grassroots level.
In line with the new Nigeria OCS, the Strengthening Public Finance in Nigeria (STREPFIN 2) project falls under the Novib#s Aim 4 programme, #Right to be Heard.# The programme 4 centres on the protection, promotion, respect and fulfilment of civil and political rights, while its intervention is on creating access to information, access to justice, promoting public participation and transparency and space for civil society.

participating-org.narrative:
ActionAid Nigeria (AAN) is a local Non-Governmental Organization. It is an affiliate of ActionAid International and also registeredwith CAC in Nigeria. ActionAid Nigeria commenced programme operations in Nigeria in January 2000 and currently operates inalmost all the 36 states and the Federal Capital Territory of Nigeria. Its programmes are spread in Six Thematic Areas; Democracy and Governance; Health, Education, Food and Agriculture, Conflict and Human security and women#s rights. Linking all theseis the geographically based integrated Local Rights Program (LRP) # a long term partnership and engagement strategy which is being implemented in twelve states of the federation.
ActionAid Nigeria continually works with community based organisations in its local Rights Programme, strengthening the capacity of partners to carry out voter education which helps curb violence and other electoral vices. It also supports partner organisations to embark on budget tracking and monitoring activities and to conduct capacity building workshops in their communities to observe and question public service delivery. Its head office is in Abuja, a southern regional office in Lagos and project offices spread across different parts of the country. Since the year 2000,AAN has partnered and administered grants to over200 Civil Society Organizations across the 36 states and FCT of Nigeria. Its current annual budget is over $7m drawn from institutional donors and sponsorship Program (where individuals from across some Northern Countries, commit a particular amount periodically,to sponsoring and caring for children). Currently, AAN manages over 50 CSOs in delivering various programs and projects, across Nigeria
The strength of its systems and processes is demonstrated from our partnership framework/process (Partnership Assessment Development Framework # PADEF), specifically developed by ActionAid Nigeria and now adopted by several international agencies in and outside Nigeria. It has over seventy (70) experienced, well-motivated and passionate staff spread across various offices in the Country.Almost 70% of these staff are based in AAN#s head office in Abuja while others are in their southern regional office in Lagos and project offices spread across the country.
Financial system and capacity. ActionAid uses SUN system account package to capture all its project expenses and the Vision reporting software to generate all donor reports. This helps ensure accuracy and timeliness. ActionAid financial year end is 31stDecember of every year. it has an internal auditor office (with two Professional auditors # all chartered accountants). The office assesses financial transactions, systems and audits project expenses and partners on a regular basis or based on need. In addition, ActionAid International Internal auditors audit the Country Program every two years. Some projects are also audited based on donor requirements. ActionAid Nigeria as a statutory requirement carries out annual audit of its financial statements. The current external auditor is Ernst and Young Chartered Accountants
Procurement Process ActionAid has a procurement policy that guides its procurement procedures and has a procurement committee that procures all goods and services above N100,000.00 whilethose below the amount is procured by the requesting unit but guided by the procurement policy.
